questions.question: Which type of friction acts between two surfaces that are not currently sliding past each other?
questions.explanation: Static friction acts when surfaces are not sliding relative to each other.

questions.question: The magnitude of the friction force is directly proportional to which other force?
questions.explanation: Friction models: $f_s \leq \mu_s F_N$, $f_k = \mu_k F_N$. Friction âˆ normal force.

questions.question: For most material pairs, the coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) is generally:
options: Less than the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$).
Greater than the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$).
Exactly equal to the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$).
questions.explanation: Static friction is typically harder to overcome, so $\mu_s > \mu_k$ for most materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the magnitude of static friction ($f_s$)?
options: It is always a constant value regardless of the push.
It adjusts its magnitude to match the applied force up to a certain maximum.
It is always equal to $\mu_s F_N$ as long as the object is at rest.
It only exists when an object is moving at constant velocity.
questions.explanation: Static friction adjusts to match applied force until maximum: $f_s \leq \mu_s F_N$.

questions.question: A $20\text{ kg}$ box rests on a floor where the maximum static friction is $98\text{ N}$. If you push it with a horizontal force of $50\text{ N}$ and it does not move, what is the actual static friction force?
questions.explanation: Since box doesn't move, static friction balances applied force: $f_s = 50\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Once an object begins to slide, the friction force acting on it is called:
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction acts when surfaces are sliding relative to each other.

questions.question: What happens to the friction force when an object transitions from being 'on the verge of sliding' to actually sliding?
options: It typically drops to a lower constant value.
questions.explanation: Static friction maximum $\mu_s F_N$ is typically greater than kinetic friction $\mu_k F_N$, so force drops.

questions.question: Kinetic friction is generally independent of which of the following?
options: The sliding speed and contact area.
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction depends on materials and normal force, but is generally independent of speed and contact area.

questions.question: The coefficients of friction ($\mu_s$ and $\mu_k$) are 'dimensionless.' This means:
options: They have no units of measurement.
They only apply to objects with no mass.
questions.explanation: Coefficients of friction are ratios, so they have no units.

questions.question: Which material combination would likely have the lowest coefficient of friction?
questions.explanation: Ice on steel is very slippery and has a very low coefficient of friction.

scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the difference between static and kinetic friction.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on how friction relates to normal force.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study the properties of static and kinetic friction carefully.
